qas.question: USB cables and device have only what on their ends?
Hosts and devices only have what in terms of connecting to a USB device?
Devices usually have what type of receptacle?
Hosts almost always have what type of receptacle?

context: In general, USB cables have only <a0_0>plugs<a0_0/> on their ends, while hosts and devices have only <a1_0>receptacles<a1_0/>. Hosts almost universally have <a3_0>Type-A receptacles<a3_0/>, while devices have <a2_0>one or another Type-B variety<a2_0/>. Type-A plugs mate only with Type-A receptacles, and the same applies to their Type-B counterparts; they are deliberately physically incompatible. However, an extension to the USB standard specification called USB On-The-Go (OTG) allows a single port to act as either a host or a device, which is selectable by the end of the cable that plugs into the receptacle on the OTG-enabled unit. Even after the cable is hooked up and the units are communicating, the two units may "swap" ends under program control. This capability is meant for units such as PDAs in which the USB link might connect to a PC's host port as a device in one instance, yet connect as a host itself to a keyboard and mouse device in another instance.
